page.title: 4.3.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will continue to develop your ability to interpret statements in function notation in terms of a situation, including reasoning about inequalities.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe the connections between a statement in function notation and the graph of the function.
  • Use function notation to efficiently represent a relationship between two quantities in a situation.
  • Use statements in function notation to sketch a graph of a function.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 4.3.1: Comparing Function Values
  • 4.3.2: Writing Statements from Function Notation
  • 4.3.2: Self Check
  • 4.3.3: Comparing Statements in Function Notation
  • 4.3.3: Self Check
  • 4.3.4: Using Function Notation with a Real-World Example

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 4.3.5: Practice
  • 4.3.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 4.3.1: Comparing Function Values
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity


Here is a graph that represents function \(f\), which gives the height of a drone, in meters, \(t\) seconds after it leaves the ground.

Decide which function value is greater.


  1. \(f(0)\) or \(f(4)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(f(4)\)



  1. \(f(2)\) or \(f(5)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

They are equal.



  1. \(f(3)\) or \(f(7)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(f(3)\)



  1. \(f(t)\) or \(f(t+1)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It depends on the value of \(t\).

page.title: 4.3.2: Writing Statements from Function Notation
page.contents:
Activity

The function \(P\) gives the number of people, in millions, who own a smartphone, \(t\) years after the year 2000. So, any value for which \(t\) is negative would represent the number of years before 2000.

  1. What does each equation tell us about smartphone ownership?
    1. \(P(17)=2320\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

In 2017, about 2,320 million or 2.32 billion people owned a smartphone.


    1. \(P(-10)=0\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

No one owned a smartphone in 1990, 10 years before 2000.




  1. Use function notation to represent each statement.
    1. In 2010, the number of people who owned a smartphone was 296,600,000.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(P(10) = 296.6\)




    1. In 2015, about 1.86 billion people owned a smartphone.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(P(15) = 1860\)




  1. Mai is curious about the value of \(t\) in \(P(t)=1000\).
    1. What would the value of \(t\) tell Mai about the situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

the year when 1 billion people owned a smartphone (adding the value of \(t\) to 2000 gives the year)




    1. Is 4 a possible value of \(t\) here?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

No. \(t=4\) corresponds to the year 2004. At that time, the number of smartphone owners should be below that of 2010, which was 296 million.




  1. Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course. Use the information you have so far to sketch a graph of the function.

    Your graph should go through these three points: \((-10,0)\), \((10,296.6)\), \((15,1860)\), and \((17,2320)\).

Then select the Solution button to check your work.



Compare your answers:

Extending Your Thinking

What can you say about the value or values of \(t\) when \(P(t)=1000\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

There is not enough information to know exactly when 1 billion (1,000 million) people owned a smartphone, but there is likely only one value of \(t\) when \(P(t)=1000\), and that value is somewhere between 10 and 15. This is because the number of smartphone users was less than a billion in 2010 and more than a billion in 2015.

page.title: 4.3.2: Self Check
page.contents: The function \(Q\) gives the number of people, in millions, who owned a smart watch after 2015. What does the equation \(Q(6)=7.25\) mean?

answer.answer_text: In 2006, 7.25 million people owned smart watches.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The 6 represents the years after 2015, not 2000. The answer is in 2021, 7.25 million people owned smart watches.

answer.answer_text: In the beginning of 2023, 6 million people owned smart watches.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 6 is the number of years after 2015. The 7.25 is the millions of people, not the years. The answer is in 2021, 7.25 million people owned smart watches.

answer.answer_text: In 2021, 7.25 million people owned smart watches.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: 2021 is 6 years after 2015 and the function, \(Q\), gives the number in millions, so 7.25 million people owned smart watches in 2021.

answer.answer_text: In 2021, 7.25 million more people owned smart watches than in 2015.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The function, \(Q\), gives the number of people who owned the smart watches in the year, not how many more people owned them than in 2015. The answer is in 2021, 7.25 million people owned smart watches.

page.title: 4.3.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Interpreting Equations in Function Notation

What does a statement like \(p(3)=12\) mean?

On its own, \(p(3)=12\) only tells us that when \(p\) takes 3 as its input, its output is 12.

If we know what quantities the input and output represent, however, we can learn much more about the situation that the function represents.

If function \(p\) gives the perimeter of a square whose side length is \(x\) and both measurements are in inches, then we can interpret \(p(3)=12\) to mean “a square whose side length is 3 inches has a perimeter of 12 inches.”

We can also interpret statements like \(p(3)=12\) to mean “a square with side length \(x\) has a perimeter of 32 inches,” which then allows us to reason that \(x\) must be 8 inches and to write \(p(8)=32\).

If function \(p\) gives the number of blog subscribers, in thousands, \(x\) months after a blogger started publishing online, then \(p(3)=12\) means “3 months after a blogger started publishing online, the blog has 12,000 subscribers.”

It is important to pay attention to the units of measurement when analyzing a function. Otherwise, we might mistake what is happening in the situation. If we miss that \(p(x)\) is measured in thousands, we might misinterpret \(p(36)\) to mean “there are 36 blog subscribers after \(x\) months,” while it actually means “after 36 months, there are \(x\) thousands of blog subscribers.”

Try It: Interpret Equations in Function Notation


If a function \(A\) gives the area of a square, with a side length \(x\) centimeters, then what does the function \(A(8)=64\) mean?

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to interpret the function notation in the equation:

Since \(A\) gives the area and 8 is the input, a square with side length of 8 centimeters has an area of 64 \(cm^2\).

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.3.3: Comparing Statements in Function Notation
page.contents:
Activity

The function \(W\) gives the temperature, in degrees Fahrenheit, of a pot of water on a stove, \(t\) minutes after the stove is turned on.

  1. Take turns with your partner to explain the meaning of each statement in this situation. When it’s your partner’s turn, listen carefully to their interpretation. If you disagree, discuss your thinking and work to reach an agreement.

  1. \(W(0)=72\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample response: The temperature when the stove was turned on was 72 degrees Fahrenheit.



  1. \(W(5)>W(2)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample response: The temperature after 5 minutes was warmer than the temperature after 2 minutes.



  1. \(W(10)=212\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample response: The temperature of the water after 10 minutes was 212 degrees Fahrenheit.



  1. \(W(12)=W(10)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample response: The temperature of the water was the same after 10 minutes and after 12 minutes.



  1. \(W(15)>W(30)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample response: The temperature after 15 minutes was higher than the temperature after 30 minutes.



  1. \(W(0)<W(30)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample response: The temperature when the stove was turned on was lower than the temperature 30 minutes later.



  1. Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course. If all statements in the previous question represent the situation, sketch a possible graph of function \(W\).

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:


Video: Understanding Equations in Function Notation

Watch the following video to learn more about reading equations in function notation.

page.title: 4.3.3: Self Check
page.contents:
The function \(C\) gives the temperature, in degrees Fahrenheit, of a pot of coffee \(x\) minutes after it is made.

What does the statement \(C(10)<C(5)\) mean in the context of the problem?

answer.answer_text: The coffee pot has less coffee in it after 10 minutes than after 5 minutes.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The function \(C\) determines the temperature, not the amount of coffee. The answer is the temperature of the coffee after 10 minutes was cooler than after 5 minutes.

answer.answer_text: The temperature of the coffee after 10 minutes was cooler than after 5 minutes.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The function \(C\) stands for coffee temperature at a particular time. The temperature at 10 minutes was less than it was at 5 minutes.

answer.answer_text: The temperature of the coffee after 10 minutes was warmer than after 5 minutes.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The coffee temperature after 10 minutes is less than after 5 minutes. The correct answer is the temperature of the coffee after 10 minutes was cooler than after 5 minutes.

answer.answer_text: The temperature of coffee after 10 hours was cooler than after 5 hours.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The time was measured in minutes, not hours. The answer is the temperature of the coffee after 10 minutes was cooler than after 5 minutes.

page.title: 4.3.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Comparing Outputs

Function \(f\) gives the depth, in inches, of water in a tub as a function of time, \(t\), in minutes, since the tub started being drained.

Each point on the graph has the coordinates \((t,f(t))\), where the first value is the input of the function and the second value is the output.

  • \(f(2)\) represents the depth of water 2 minutes after the tub started being drained. The graph passes through \((2,5)\), so the depth of water is 5 inches when \(t=2\). The equation \(f(2)=5\) captures this information.
  • \(f(0)\) gives the depth of the water when the draining began, at \(t=0\). The graph shows the depth of water to be 6 inches at that time, so we can write \(f(0)=6\).
  • \(f(t)=3\) tells us that \(t\) minutes after the tub started draining, the depth of the water is 3 inches. The graph shows that this happens when \(t\) is 6.
  • In the graph, \(f(2)>f(7)\).
  • \(f(7)=f(10)\)
  • \(f(4)<f(6)\)
  • \(f(0)=6\)

Try It: Comparing Outputs

Function \(P\) gives the depth of the pool water after \(t\) hours of it being refilled.


What does the statement \(P(12)<P(4)\) mean in the context of the situation?

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find meaning in the statement:

The statement reads “\(P\) of 12 is less than \(P\) of 4.” The input is the time in hours, and the output is the depth of the pool. So, the depth of the pool after 12 hours is less than it was after 4 hours.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.3.4: Using Function Notation with a Real-World Example
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

An art museum opens at 9 a.m. and closes at 5 p.m. The function \(V\) gives the number of visitors in the museum \(h\) hours after it opens.



  1. Explain what this statement tells us about the situation: \(V(1.25) = 28\).

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

An hour and 15 minutes after the museum opened (at 10:15 a.m.), there were 28 visitors in the building.



  1. Use function notation to represent each statement:
    1. At 1 p.m., there were 257 visitors in the museum.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(V(4)=257\)



    1. At the time of closing, there were no visitors in the museum.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(V(8)=0\)


    1. Use the previous statements about the visitors in the museum to sketch a graph that could represent the function.


Use the graphing tool here or technology outside the course. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Your graph should show points at \((1.25,28)\) and \((4,257)\), with or without lines connecting these points.

Compare your answer:

page.title: 4.3.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. Function \(f\) gives the temperature, in degrees Celsius, \(t\) hours after midnight.

Choose which equation or expression represents the statement in function notation.

  1. The temperature was the same at 9 a.m. and at 4 p.m.

Correct! \(f(9)=f(16)\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f(9)=f(16)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. It was warmer at 9 a.m. than at 6 a.m.

Correct! \(f(9) > f(6)\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f(9) > f(6)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Some time after midnight, the temperature was 24 degrees Celsius.

Correct! \(f(t)=24\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f(t)=24\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Select all points that are on the graph of \(f\) if we know that \(f(2)=-4\) and \(f(5)=3.4\).

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are \((2, -4)\), \((5, 3.4)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Looking at the graph of the function \(g\), below, which is greater, \(g(-5)\) or \(g(5)\)?

Correct! \(g(-5)\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.3.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(g(-5)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The function \(T\) tells how many people are living on floor \(n\) of an apartment building. What does \(T(4)=82\) mean?

Correct! In 1980, the world population increased by 80 million people.

Try again. WhyTry again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.2.1-4.2.2. Are you using it the right way

The correct answer is: In 1980, the world population increased by 80 million people. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The function, \(T\), gives the temperature of a house, in degrees Fahrenheit, \(h\) hours after midnight. Choose which function notation represents the temperature at 6 a.m. was 70 degrees.

Correct! \(T(6)=70\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(T(6)=70\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graph below represents a function, \(f\), which gives the height of a drone, in meters, \(t\) seconds after it leaves the ground. Which statement describes the point \(f(2)=4\)?

Correct! The height of the drone after 2 seconds is 4 meters off the ground.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The height of the drone after 2 seconds is 4 meters off the ground. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 4.3.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Describe the connections between a statement in function notation and the graph of the function.
  • Use function notation to efficiently represent a relationship between two quantities in a situation.
  • Use statements in function notation to sketch a graph of a function.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 4.3.1: Comparing Function Values
    • In this activity, you compared function values given function notation and a graph.
  • 4.3.2: Writing Statements from Function Notation
    • In this activity, you interpreted the meaning of function notation in a given situation and wrote a statement describing the situation.
  • 4.3.2: Self Check
  • 4.3.3: Comparing Statements in Function Notation
    • In this activity, you interpreted equations and inequalities involving function notation to compare which values were equal, larger, or smaller.
  • 4.3.3: Self Check
  • 4.3.4: Using Function Notation with a Real-World Example
    • In this activity, you looked at a real-world example of function notation where time was the input and the number of visitors to a website was the output.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 4.3.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
